repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - First, Second, Third, and
            Fourth Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The four projects examined for Sierra
            Leone, the First, Second, Third, and Fourth Economic
            Rehabilitation and Recovery (ERR) Project. Ratings for the
            First, Second, Third Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery
            Credit Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Fourth Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery Credit Grant
            Project were as follows:  outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            and the Bank and the Borrower performance were satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included:  overall, the ERR operations
            were effective in providing critical budget support to
            Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL) during the initial
            post-conflict years. The effectiveness was greater in
            directly supporting the demobilization effort under the DDR
            program, achieving the initial protective, social, and
            economic security advances, and in accomplishing process
            improvements, than in achieving better governance, improved
            allocation of budget resources and development results in
            the longer run. Early start of Bank interventions and
            informed risk taking can help consolidate the peace process.
            Delayed adoption of a country strategy and programmatic
            budget support weakens ownership, creates funding
            uncertainty, and hampers capacity building under the
            circumstances. Stronger signaling of longer-term resource
            availability for budget support and capacity-building
            substitutes for the lack of formal programmatic framework.
            While project or program designs were kept simple and
            realistic, more could have been done to develop an
            appropriate results framework calibrated to post-conflict
            country circumstances. The Bank is (often) expected to
            assume a leading role in mobilizing and coordinating
            external donor assistance in post-conflict situations, and
            is not always adequately resourced to do this. In
            recognition of this, post-conflict Bank programs may benefit
            from senior management support that would enable country
            teams to more appropriately structure and adequately
            resource their efforts in mobilizing and coordinating donor assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Fourth Economic
            Rehabilitation and Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sierra Leone Fourth Economic
            Rehabilitation and Recovery Project (ERRC IV) has a
            satisfactory outcome, is likely to be sustainable, and has a
            substantial institutional development impact. The
            performances of both the Bank and the Borrower are
            satisfactory. The lessons cited from this project echoed
            lessons learned from ERRC I-III, and are recommended for
            other countries characterized by low capacity, resulting
            from conflict or other causes, and high aid dependency. They
            include: not relying on the single tranche model as a
            guarantee of predictable funds release; being proactive in
            facilitating good outcome; reducing the number and
            complexity of conditions and aligning them with the
            administrative and implementing capacity of Government;
            finding an   empowered leader from within the Government to
            coordinate implementation of the reform program; being
            prepared to invest extra resources into the supervision
            effort; seeking a better fit between triggers, the degree of
            consensus within Government leadership circles, and the
            degree of technical and administrative capacity within
            implementing ministries; and  embarking on a medium-term
            comprehensive program of capacity building. The report also
            pointed out that the partnership and coordination between
            the World Bank, the Government, and other international
            donors can lead to successful achievements as demonstrated
            by the outcome of the credit; Bank support for policy
            reforms should therefore continue to seek to integrate the
            efforts of other active donors.

6228047.majtheme: Public sector governance,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Fourth Economic
            Rehabilitation and Recovery Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Economic Rehabilitation and
            Recovery Grant (ERRG4) Project will provide quick disbursing
            support to the Government's 2005 budget in a single
            tranche. This project (the fourth in a series), is designed
            to consolidate Sierra Leone's transition from
            peace-keeping and relief aid, to equitable and sustainable
            development, in the context of Sierra Leone's Poverty
            Reduction Strategy. The ERRG4 will provide critical
            resources to consolidate and deepen the agenda set by the
            ERRC series, including progress made in governance,
            decentralization of government, management of public
            resources, human resource development, and private
            sector-led economic growth. The grant will contribute to
            economic recovery and growth, by providing foreign exchange
            resources for the imports of essential commodities, by
            providing financial resources to the Government budget, to
            finance priority public expenditures, and by supporting
            reforms to attract private investment. In helping to close
            the financing gap in 2005, it will also contribute to
            maintaining macroeconomic stability, and low inflation.
            However risks include delayed or inadequate public services
            that could exacerbate poverty, and possibly lead to social
            unrest; the budget is heavily dependent upon external
            assistance; macroeconomic stability could prove difficult to
            maintain; and, weak institutional capacity could cause
            delays in implementing the program; and, conflict in
            neighboring Cote d'Ivoire may affect trade, or spill
            over into Sierra Leone, while slow or incomplete disarmament
            in Liberia could create tensions between Guinea and Sierra
            Leone, which could spark a new war.
